conclusion: To determine the proportionality constant k in the air resistance force f = k m^{1/3} v, analyze the motion of the oil droplets under gravity, air resistance, and electric force.
Analyze the motion of the droplets without the electric field.
When no voltage is applied, both droplets A and B fall with a uniform velocity v_1.
The force due to gravity on droplet A or B is m_0 g.
The air resistance force is f = k m_0^{1/3} v_1.
Since the droplets move at a constant velocity, the forces are balanced: m_0 g = k m_0^{1/3} v_1.
Analyze the motion of droplet B in the electric field.
When the voltage U is applied, droplet B moves upwards with a uniform velocity v_2.
The electric force acts upwards, and the forces acting on droplet B are gravity m_0 g downward, air resistance f = k m_0^{1/3} v_2 downward, and electric force F_e = q U/d upward.
For uniform motion of droplet B: q U/d = m_0 g + k m_0^{1/3} v_2.
Analyze the motion of droplet A in the electric field.
Droplet A continues to fall with the same velocity v_1.
The forces on droplet A are gravity m_0 g downward, air resistance f = k m_0^{1/3} v_1 upward, and electric force F_e = q U/d upward.
For uniform motion of droplet A: m_0 g = k m_0^{1/3} v_1 + q U/d.
Solving the equations for uniform motion without the electric field.
From the uniform motion without the electric field: m_0 g = k m_0^{1/3} v_1.
Solve for k: k = m_0^{2/3} g / v_1.

Calculate k using the expression derived.
